Note: Participant notices that watching video while glasses transcribe live audio is not overwhelming and feels that eyes shift seamlessly between external screen and MR glasses display
Participant notes that live captioning feature accurately reflects audio
Participant positions head and eyes just above the phone screen so that MR glasses display the live captions slightly above the video

Participant expresses dislike for the live captioning feature as they feel like they have to be more conscious of head positioning since they must focus on both MR display and phone screen (head or phone must be placed in a specific position to avoid jumbled content) and neck feels strained
Participant says that users might enjoy the live captioning feature more if they are unable to watch something but can still hear and see live captions in the glasses

Participant does not see a purpose in the live captioning feature and says their opinion would not change even if they were watching content on a bigger screen while MR glasses displayed live captions
Participant notices that captions are slightly delayed but not too slow and expresses general satisfaction
Participant notices that Meta remains stuck on past information requests and expresses light annoyance
Area around the nose gets sore. Padding might be helpful especially for someone not used to wearing glasses
Phone #9 randomly updated software but turned off completely and would not turn on even when plugged into charger
Phone was off and Bluetooth in MR glasses disconnected for about 3 minutes. Participant could still hear Meta tell them that Bluetooth needed to be reconnected
Participant believes that if users are not comfortable or familiar with hand gestures, scrolling through many images could feel draining
Participant notices that glasses slide forward and they must continuously adjust them when head is tilted forward during Lego-building
Participant described video call quality as “pretty good and clear” and says that users might benefit from looking through toward a dark solid background
Participant notices that MR display does a good job at creating enough contrast between different shades of the same color when looking at Lego instruction images

Participant notices that MR display is less helpful when details surrounding shapes and sizes are important (participant was struggling to determine the difference in image instructions between two Lego shapes that look similar from top view angle)

Participant believes that the image instructions within the glasses make building the Legos easier compared to if they had the image instructions in a physical booklet in front of them partly because the scrolling motion is quick with the hand gestures and because the images are right in front of their hands.
